\title{atlas Documentation}

\phantomsection\label{\detokenize{index::doc}}


Atlas is a small software developed to use simple text files that encode
biological networks and write Rule\sphinxhyphen{}Based Models (RBMs). Atlas writes rules and
others model components for the PySB python package \sphinxhref{http://pysb.org/}{PySB}, PMID \sphinxhref{https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/23423320}{23423320}.
The RBMs could be simulated within PySB with \sphinxhref{https://github.com/RuleWorld/nfsim}{NFsim}, PMID \sphinxhref{https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/26556387}{26556387} (within
the \sphinxhref{https://github.com/RuleWorld/bionetgen}{BioNetGen2} software, PMID \sphinxhref{https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/27402907}{27402907}), KaSim (\sphinxhref{https://github.com/Kappa-Dev/KaSim}{KaSim}, PMID
\sphinxhref{https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/29950016}{29950016}). Models could be exported to text files in \sphinxstyleemphasis{BioNetGen}
(\sphinxhref{http://www.csb.pitt.edu/Faculty/Faeder/?page\_id=409}{BioNetGenLanguage}) or \sphinxstyleemphasis{kappa} language (\sphinxhref{https://www.kappalanguage.org/}{Kappa}) for further calibration
(\sphinxhref{https://github.com/RuleWorld/BioNetFit}{BioNetFit}, PMID \sphinxhref{https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/26556387}{26556387} or \sphinxhref{https://github.com/networkbiolab/pleione}{pleione}, PMID \sphinxhref{https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/31641245}{31641245}) and analysis
(\sphinxhref{https://github.com/networkbiolab/sterope}{sterope} for parameter sensibility and \sphinxhref{https://github.com/networkbiolab/alcyone}{alcyone} for parameter uncertainty).


\chapter{Installation}
\label{\detokenize{Installation:installation}}\label{\detokenize{Installation::doc}}
There are two different ways to install Atlas:
\begin{enumerate}
\sphinxsetlistlabels{\arabic}{enumi}{enumii}{}{.}%
\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{Install Atlas natively (Recommended).}

\sphinxstyleemphasis{OR}

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{Clone the Github repository.} If you are familiar with git, Atlas can
be cloned and the respective folder added to the python path. Further details
are below.

\end{enumerate}

\begin{sphinxadmonition}{note}{Note:}
\sphinxstylestrong{Need Help?}
If you run into any problems with installation, please visit our chat room:
\sphinxurl{https://gitter.im/glucksfall/pleiades}
\end{sphinxadmonition}


\section{Option 1: Install Atlas natively on your computer}
\label{\detokenize{Installation:option-1-install-atlas-natively-on-your-computer}}
The recommended approach is to use system tools, or install them if
necessary. To install python packages, you could use pip, or download
the package from the \sphinxhref{https://pypi.org/project/atlas-rbm/}{python package index}.
\begin{enumerate}
\sphinxsetlistlabels{\arabic}{enumi}{enumii}{}{.}%
\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{Install with system tools}

With pip, you need to execute and Atlas will be installed on
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{\$HOME/.local/lib/python3.6/site\sphinxhyphen{}packages}} folder or similar.

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
pip3 install atlas\PYGZus{}rbm \PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}user
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

If you have system rights, you could install Atlas for all users with

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
sudo \PYGZhy{}H pip3 install atlas\PYGZus{}rbm
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{Download from the python package index}

Alternatively, you could download the package (useful when pip fails to download
the package because of lack of SSL libraries) and then install with pip. For instance:

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
wget https://files.pythonhosted.org/packages/ec/ed/8b94e0a29f69a24ddb18ba4a4e6463d3ecede308576774e86baf6a84b998/atlas\PYGZus{}rbm\PYGZhy{}1.0.2\PYGZhy{}py3\PYGZhy{}none\PYGZhy{}any.whl
pip3 install atlas\PYGZus{}rbm\PYGZhy{}1.0.2\PYGZhy{}py3\PYGZhy{}none\PYGZhy{}any.whl \PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}user
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

\begin{sphinxadmonition}{note}{Note:}
\sphinxstylestrong{Why Python3?}:
Atlas is intended to be used with \textgreater{}=python3.4 because python2.7 won’t receive
further development past 2020, including security updates.
\end{sphinxadmonition}

\begin{sphinxadmonition}{note}{Note:}
\sphinxstylestrong{pip, Python, and Anaconda}:
Be aware which pip you invoque. You could install pip3 with
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{sudo apt\sphinxhyphen{}get install python3\sphinxhyphen{}pip}} if you have system rights, or
install python3 from source, and adding \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{\textless{}python3 path\textgreater{}/bin/pip3}} to the
path, or linking it in a directory like \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{\$HOME/bin}} which is commonly
added to the path at login. Also be aware that, if you installed
Anaconda, pip could be linked to the Anaconda specific version of pip, which
will install Atlas into Anaconda’s installation folder.
Type \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{which pip}} or \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{which pip3}} to find out the source of pip, and type
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{python \sphinxhyphen{}m site}} or \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{python3 \sphinxhyphen{}m site}} to find out where is more likely
Atlas will be installed.
\end{sphinxadmonition}

\end{enumerate}


\section{Option 2: Clone the Github repository}
\label{\detokenize{Installation:option-2-clone-the-github-repository}}\begin{enumerate}
\sphinxsetlistlabels{\arabic}{enumi}{enumii}{}{.}%
\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{Clone with git}

The source code is uploaded and maintained through Github at
\sphinxurl{https://github.com/networkbiolab/atlas}. Therefore, you could clone the
repository locally, and then add the folder to the \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{PYTHONPATH}}. Beware
that you should install the \sphinxstyleemphasis{pysb} package (\sphinxhref{http://pysb.org/}{pysb}) and others packages
by any means, specially the Jupyter Notebook project (\sphinxurl{https://jupyter.org}).

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{n+nv}{path}\PYG{o}{=}/opt/atlas
git clone https://github.com/networkbiolab/atlas \PYG{n+nv}{\PYGZdl{}path}
\PYG{n+nb}{echo} \PYG{n+nb}{export} \PYG{n+nv}{PYTHONPATH}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}\PYGZbs{}\PYGZdl{}PYTHONPATH:\PYGZbs{}\PYGZdl{}path\PYGZdq{}} \PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{} \PYG{n+nv}{\PYGZdl{}HOME}/.profile
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

\begin{sphinxadmonition}{note}{Note:}
Adding the path to \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{\$HOME/.profile}} allows python to find the package
installation folder after each user login. Similarly, adding the path to
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{\$HOME/.bashrc}} allows python to find the package after each terminal
invocation. Other options include setting the \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{PYTHONPATH}} environmental
variable in a sh file (see the example folder) or invoke \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{python3 setup.py clean build install}}
to install Atlas as it was downloaded from the PyPI server.
\end{sphinxadmonition}

\end{enumerate}


\chapter{Modeling}
\label{\detokenize{Modeling:modeling}}\label{\detokenize{Modeling::doc}}
Atlas is a modular software with each script centered in a specific biological
network
\begin{enumerate}
\sphinxsetlistlabels{\arabic}{enumi}{enumii}{}{.}%
\item {} 
{\hyperref[\detokenize{NetMetabolic:net-metabolic}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{std,std-ref}{Metabolic Networks}}}}

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{Interaction Networks}
\begin{enumerate}
\sphinxsetlistlabels{\arabic}{enumii}{enumiii}{}{.}%
\item {} 
{\hyperref[\detokenize{NetProteinProtein:net-proteinprotein}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{std,std-ref}{Protein\sphinxhyphen{}Protein Interaction Networks}}}}

\item {} 
{\hyperref[\detokenize{NetProteinSmallCompounds:net-protein-smallcompounds}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{std,std-ref}{Protein\sphinxhyphen{}Small compounds Interaction Networks}}}}

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{Protein\sphinxhyphen{}RNA Interaction Networks}

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{RNA\sphinxhyphen{}RNA Interaction Networks}

\item {} 
{\hyperref[\detokenize{NetTFsDNABindingSites:net-tfsdnabindingsites}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{std,std-ref}{Transcription Factor\sphinxhyphen{}DNA Binding Site Interaction Networks}}}}

\item {} 
{\hyperref[\detokenize{NetSFsPromoters:net-sfspromoters}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{std,std-ref}{Sigma Factor\sphinxhyphen{}Promoter Interaction Networks}}}}

\end{enumerate}

\item {} 
{\hyperref[\detokenize{NetGenomeGraphs:net-genomegraphs}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{std,std-ref}{Genome Graphs}}}}

\end{enumerate}


\section{Metabolic Networks}
\label{\detokenize{NetMetabolic:metabolic-networks}}\label{\detokenize{NetMetabolic:net-metabolic}}\label{\detokenize{NetMetabolic::doc}}
Metabolic networks have four columns. The first declares a unique name for the
enzyme or enzymatic complex; the second declares a unique name for the reaction;
the third column lists using comma unique names for substrates; and the last row
list using comma unique names for products. To declare metabolites located at
the periplasm or extracellular compartments, the user should employ the prefix
“PER\sphinxhyphen{}” and “EX\sphinxhyphen{}”, respectively. Use \sphinxstyleemphasis{spontaneous} for non\sphinxhyphen{}enzymatic reactions.

Examples:

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\},numbers=left,firstnumber=1,stepnumber=1]
\PYG{n}{GENE}	\PYG{n}{REACTION}	\PYG{n}{SUBSTRATES}	\PYG{n}{PRODUCTS}	\PYG{n}{FWD\PYGZus{}RATE}	\PYG{n}{RVS\PYGZus{}RATE}
\PYG{n}{spontaneous}	\PYG{n}{LACTOSE}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{n}{MUTAROTATION}	\PYG{n}{alpha}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{n}{lactose}	\PYG{n}{beta}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{n}{lactose}	\PYG{l+m+mf}{1.0}	\PYG{l+m+mf}{1.0}
\PYG{n}{spontaneous}	\PYG{n}{GALACTOSE}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{n}{MUTAROTATION}	\PYG{n}{alpha}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{n}{GALACTOSE}	\PYG{n}{beta}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{n}{GALACTOSE}	\PYG{l+m+mf}{1.0}	\PYG{l+m+mf}{1.0}
\PYG{n}{spontaneous}	\PYG{n}{GLUCOSE}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{n}{MUTAROTATION}	\PYG{n}{alpha}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{n}{glucose}	\PYG{n}{beta}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{n}{glucose}	\PYG{l+m+mf}{1.0}	\PYG{l+m+mf}{1.0}
\PYG{n}{MEM}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{n}{LACY}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{n}{MONOMER}	\PYG{n}{TRANS}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{n}{RXN}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{l+m+mi}{24}	\PYG{n}{PER}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{n}{PROTON}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{PER}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{n}{alpha}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{n}{lactose}	\PYG{n}{PROTON}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{alpha}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{n}{lactose}	\PYG{l+m+mf}{1.0}	\PYG{l+m+mf}{0.0}
\PYG{n}{MEM}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{n}{LACY}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{n}{MONOMER}	\PYG{n}{TRANS}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{n}{RXN}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{l+m+mi}{24}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{n}{beta}	\PYG{n}{PER}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{n}{PROTON}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{PER}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{n}{beta}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{n}{lactose}	\PYG{n}{PROTON}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{beta}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{n}{lactose}	\PYG{l+m+mf}{1.0}	\PYG{l+m+mf}{0.0}
\PYG{n}{MEM}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{n}{LACY}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{n}{MONOMER}	\PYG{n}{TRANS}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{n}{RXN}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{l+m+mi}{94}	\PYG{n}{PER}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{n}{PROTON}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{PER}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{n}{MELIBIOSE}	\PYG{n}{PROTON}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{MELIBIOSE}	\PYG{l+m+mf}{1.0}	\PYG{l+m+mf}{1.0}
\PYG{n}{MEM}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{n}{LACY}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{n}{MONOMER}	\PYG{n}{RXN0}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{l+m+mi}{7215}	\PYG{n}{PER}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{n}{PROTON}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{PER}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{n}{CPD}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{l+m+mi}{3561}	\PYG{n}{PROTON}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{CPD}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{l+m+mi}{3561}	\PYG{l+m+mf}{1.0}	\PYG{l+m+mf}{1.0}

\begin{sphinxadmonition}{note}{Note:}
\sphinxstylestrong{Visualization in Cytoscape.} Transform the four\sphinxhyphen{}columns file into a
two\sphinxhyphen{}columns file with the helper script “\sphinxstyleemphasis{Expand metabolic network.ipynb}”, paste
the results in a new file, and import the network into Cytoscape. Colors and
arrows remains to the user for customization.

\noindent\sphinxincludegraphics{{Fig_Lactose_MetNetwork}.png}
\end{sphinxadmonition}

Finally, execute the “\sphinxstyleemphasis{Rules from metabolic network.ipynb}” to obtain the
\sphinxstyleemphasis{Rules} to model the defined metabolic network. The complete rule\sphinxhyphen{}based
model can be found in the lactose folder from the Network Biology Lab
GitHub repository \sphinxhref{https://github.com/networkbiolab/atlas/blob/master/lactose/Models/Model3\%20MetNet\%20fully\%20automatized.ipynb/}{here}.

	\PYG{n}{Parameter}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{fwd\PYGZus{}GALACTOACETYLTRAN\PYGZus{}RXN\PYGZus{}galactose}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{l+m+mi}{1}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{,}
	\PYG{n}{Parameter}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{rvs\PYGZus{}GALACTOACETYLTRAN\PYGZus{}RXN\PYGZus{}galactose}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{l+m+mi}{1}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{)}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

\begin{sphinxadmonition}{note}{Note:}
\sphinxstylestrong{Reversibility of Rules}. Atlas writes reversible \sphinxstyleemphasis{Rules} for each
reaction declared in the network file. The \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Parameter(\textquotesingle{}rvs\_RuleName\textquotesingle{}, 1))}}
must be set to zero to define an irreversible reaction.
\end{sphinxadmonition}

\begin{sphinxadmonition}{note}{Note:}
\sphinxstylestrong{Uniqueness of Rule names}. Atlas will write \sphinxstyleemphasis{Rules} for unique
metabolic reactions. Identical names will be reported for further curation.
\end{sphinxadmonition}

\begin{sphinxadmonition}{note}{Note:}
\sphinxstylestrong{Simulation}. The model can be simulated only with the instantiation of
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Monomers}} and \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Initials}} (\sphinxhref{https://pysb.readthedocs.io/en/stable/tutorial.html\#introduction}{More here}).
Run \sphinxstyleemphasis{Monomer+Initials+Observables from metabolic network.ipynb} to obtain
automatically the necessary \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Monomers}} and \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Initials}} (including
proteins and enzymatic complexes).

\sphinxstylestrong{Plotting}. The model can be observed only with the instantation of
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Observables}} (\sphinxhref{https://pysb.readthedocs.io/en/stable/tutorial.html\#simulation-and-analysis}{More here}).
Run \sphinxstyleemphasis{Monomer+Initials+Observables from metabolic network.ipynb} to obtain
automatically the all possible \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Observables}} for metabolites.
\end{sphinxadmonition}


\section{Protein\sphinxhyphen{}Protein Interaction Networks}
\label{\detokenize{NetProteinProtein:protein-protein-interaction-networks}}\label{\detokenize{NetProteinProtein:net-proteinprotein}}\label{\detokenize{NetProteinProtein::doc}}
Protein\sphinxhyphen{}protein interaction (PPI) interaction networks have two columns. In any
order and for any number of components, each column lists using comma the
interacting proteins or protein complexes. The user should employ brackets to
enclose a list of proteins that are part of a complex.

Examples:

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\},numbers=left,firstnumber=1,stepnumber=1]
\PYG{n}{SOURCE}	\PYG{n}{TARGET}
\PYG{n}{BETAGALACTOSID}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{n}{MONOMER}	\PYG{n}{BETAGALACTOSID}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{n}{MONOMER}
\PYG{n}{GALACTOACETYLTRAN}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{n}{MONOMER}	\PYG{n}{GALACTOACETYLTRAN}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{n}{MONOMER}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

\sphinxstyleemphasis{OR}

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\},numbers=left,firstnumber=1,stepnumber=1]
\PYG{n}{SOURCE}	\PYG{n}{TARGET}
\PYG{n}{BETAGALACTOSID}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{n}{MONOMER}	\PYG{n}{BETAGALACTOSID}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{n}{MONOMER}
\PYG{p}{[}\PYG{n}{BETAGALACTOSID}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{n}{MONOMER}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{BETAGALACTOSID}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{n}{MONOMER}\PYG{p}{]}	\PYG{p}{[}\PYG{n}{BETAGALACTOSID}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{n}{MONOMER}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{BETAGALACTOSID}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{n}{MONOMER}\PYG{p}{]}
\PYG{n}{GALACTOACETYLTRAN}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{n}{MONOMER}	\PYG{n}{GALACTOACETYLTRAN}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{n}{MONOMER}
\PYG{n}{GALACTOACETYLTRAN}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{n}{MONOMER}	\PYG{p}{[}\PYG{n}{GALACTOACETYLTRAN}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{n}{MONOMER}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{GALACTOACETYLTRAN}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{n}{MONOMER}\PYG{p}{]}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

\begin{sphinxadmonition}{note}{Note:}
\sphinxstylestrong{Visualization in Cytoscape.} Cytoscape cannot import hyper\sphinxhyphen{}graphs. To do so,
Create simple network and right\sphinxhyphen{}click to embed a subnetwork in the corresponding node.

\noindent\sphinxincludegraphics{{Fig_Lactose_PPINetwork}.png}
\end{sphinxadmonition}

Finally, execute the “\sphinxstyleemphasis{Rules from protein\sphinxhyphen{}protein.ipynb}” to obtain the
\sphinxstyleemphasis{Rules} to model the defined interaction network. The complete rule\sphinxhyphen{}based
model can be found in the lactose folder from the Network Biology Lab
GitHub repository \sphinxhref{https://github.com/networkbiolab/atlas/blob/master/lactose/Models/Model4\%20PPI\%20from\%20automatic\%20Rules.ipynb}{here}.

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\},numbers=left,firstnumber=1,stepnumber=1]

	\PYG{n}{prot}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{name} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{GALACTOACETYLTRAN\PYGZus{}MONOMER}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{up} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{l+m+mi}{1}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{dw} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{k+kc}{None}\PYG{p}{)} \PYG{o}{\PYGZpc{}}
	\PYG{n}{prot}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{name} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{GALACTOACETYLTRAN\PYGZus{}MONOMER}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{up} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{k+kc}{None}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{dw} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{l+m+mi}{1}\PYG{p}{)} \PYG{o}{|}
	\PYG{n}{prot}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{name} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{GALACTOACETYLTRAN\PYGZus{}MONOMER}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{up} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{l+m+mi}{1}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{dw} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{k+kc}{None}\PYG{p}{)} \PYG{o}{\PYGZpc{}}
	\PYG{n}{prot}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{name} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{GALACTOACETYLTRAN\PYGZus{}MONOMER}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{up} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{l+m+mi}{2}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{dw} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{l+m+mi}{1}\PYG{p}{)} \PYG{o}{\PYGZpc{}}
	\PYG{n}{prot}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{name} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{GALACTOACETYLTRAN\PYGZus{}MONOMER}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{up} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{k+kc}{None}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{dw} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{l+m+mi}{2}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{,}
	\PYG{n}{Parameter}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{fwd\PYGZus{}complex\PYGZus{}assembly\PYGZus{}rule\PYGZus{}3}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{l+m+mi}{1}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{,}
	\PYG{n}{Parameter}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{rvs\PYGZus{}complex\PYGZus{}assembly\PYGZus{}rule\PYGZus{}3}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{l+m+mi}{0}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{)}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

\begin{sphinxadmonition}{note}{Note:}
\sphinxstylestrong{Reversibility of Rules}. Atlas writes irreversible \sphinxstyleemphasis{Rules} for each
reaction declared in the network file. The \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Parameter(\textquotesingle{}rvs\_RuleName\textquotesingle{}, 0))}}
must be set to non\sphinxhyphen{}zero to define an reversible reaction.
\end{sphinxadmonition}

\begin{sphinxadmonition}{note}{Note:}
\sphinxstylestrong{Uniqueness of Rule names}. Atlas will write \sphinxstyleemphasis{Rules} with numbered
names. Use only one file to model the many interactions the system has.
\end{sphinxadmonition}

\begin{sphinxadmonition}{note}{Note:}
\sphinxstylestrong{Simulation}. The model can be simulated only with the instantiation of
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Monomers}} and \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Initials}} (\sphinxhref{https://pysb.readthedocs.io/en/stable/tutorial.html\#introduction}{More here}).
Run \sphinxstyleemphasis{Monomer+Initials+Observables from metabolic network.ipynb} to obtain
automatically the necessary \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Monomers}} and \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Initials}} (including
proteins and enzymatic complexes). Manually add the necessary \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Monomers}}
and \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Initials}} for non\sphinxhyphen{}enzymatic proteins.

\sphinxstylestrong{Plotting}. The model can be observed only with the instantation of
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Observables}} (\sphinxhref{https://pysb.readthedocs.io/en/stable/tutorial.html\#simulation-and-analysis}{More here}).
Run \sphinxstyleemphasis{Monomer+Initials+Observables from metabolic network.ipynb} to obtain
automatically the all possible \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Observables}} for enzymatic proteins. Other
observables for proteins should be added manually.
\end{sphinxadmonition}


\section{Protein\sphinxhyphen{}Small compounds Interaction Networks}
\label{\detokenize{NetProteinSmallCompounds:protein-small-compounds-interaction-networks}}\label{\detokenize{NetProteinSmallCompounds:net-protein-smallcompounds}}\label{\detokenize{NetProteinSmallCompounds::doc}}
Protein\sphinxhyphen{}small compound interaction networks have two columns. Similar to a PPI
network, but the user should add the prefix “SMALL\sphinxhyphen{}” to encode a small compound
that interacts with the protein or protein complex.

Examples:

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\},numbers=left,firstnumber=1,stepnumber=1]
\PYG{n}{SOURCE}	\PYG{n}{TARGET}
\PYG{n}{PER}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{n}{araF}	\PYG{n}{SMALL}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{n}{PER}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{n}{alpha}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{n}{L}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{n}{arabinofuranose}
\PYG{n}{PER}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{n}{araF}	\PYG{n}{SMALL}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{n}{PER}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{n}{beta}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{n}{L}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{n}{arabinofuranose}
\PYG{n}{PER}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{n}{araF}	\PYG{n}{SMALL}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{n}{PER}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{n}{alpha}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{n}{L}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{n}{arabinopyranose}
\PYG{n}{PER}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{n}{araF}	\PYG{n}{SMALL}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{n}{PER}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{n}{beta}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{n}{L}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{n}{arabinopyranose}
\PYG{p}{[}\PYG{n}{crp}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{crp}\PYG{p}{]}	\PYG{n}{SMALL}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{n}{CAMP}
\PYG{p}{[}\PYG{n}{crp}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{SMALL}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{n}{CAMP}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{crp}\PYG{p}{]}	\PYG{n}{SMALL}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{n}{CAMP}
\PYG{p}{[}\PYG{n}{lacI}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{lacI}\PYG{p}{]}	\PYG{n}{SMALL}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{n}{ALLOLACTOSE}
\PYG{p}{[}\PYG{n}{lacI}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{SMALL}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{n}{ALLOLACTOSE}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{lacI}\PYG{p}{]}	\PYG{n}{SMALL}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{n}{ALLOLACTOSE}
\PYG{p}{[}\PYG{n}{araG}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{araG}\PYG{p}{]}	\PYG{n}{SMALL}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{n}{ATP}
\PYG{n}{araC}	\PYG{n}{SMALL}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{n}{alpha}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{n}{L}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{n}{arabinopyranose}
\PYG{p}{[}\PYG{n}{araC}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{araC}\PYG{p}{]}	\PYG{n}{SMALL}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{n}{alpha}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{n}{L}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{n}{arabinopyranose}
\PYG{p}{[}\PYG{n}{araC}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{SMALL}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{n}{alpha}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{n}{L}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{n}{arabinopyranose}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{araC}\PYG{p}{]}	\PYG{n}{SMALL}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{n}{alpha}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{n}{L}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{n}{arabinopyranose}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

Finally, execute the “\sphinxstyleemphasis{Rules from protein\sphinxhyphen{}small compounds.ipynb}” to obtain the
\sphinxstyleemphasis{Rules} to model the defined interaction network. The complete rule\sphinxhyphen{}based
model can be found in the arabinose folder from the Network Biology Lab
GitHub repository \sphinxhref{https://github.com/networkbiolab/atlas/blob/master/arabinose/Model\%20arabinose\%20operon\%20Met\%20\%2B\%20PPI\%20\%2B\%20TXTL\%20\%2B\%20GRN.ipynb}{here}.

	\PYG{n}{Parameter}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{rvs\PYGZus{}ProtMet\PYGZus{}RuleAssembly\PYGZus{}11}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{l+m+mi}{1}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{)}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

\begin{sphinxadmonition}{note}{Note:}
\sphinxstylestrong{Reversibility of Rules}. Atlas writes reversible \sphinxstyleemphasis{Rules} for each
reaction declared in the network file. The \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Parameter(\textquotesingle{}rvs\_RuleName\textquotesingle{}, 1))}}
must be set to zero to define an irreversible reaction.
\end{sphinxadmonition}

\begin{sphinxadmonition}{note}{Note:}
\sphinxstylestrong{Uniqueness of Rule names}. Atlas will write \sphinxstyleemphasis{Rules} with numbered
names. Use only one file to model the many interactions the system has.
\end{sphinxadmonition}

\begin{sphinxadmonition}{note}{Note:}
\sphinxstylestrong{Simulation}. The model can be simulated only with the instantiation of
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Monomers}} and \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Initials}} (\sphinxhref{https://pysb.readthedocs.io/en/stable/tutorial.html\#introduction}{More here}).
Run \sphinxstyleemphasis{Monomer+Initials+Observables from metabolic network.ipynb} to obtain
automatically the necessary \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Monomers}} and \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Initials}} (including
proteins and enzymatic complexes). Manually add the necessary \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Monomers}}
and \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Initials}} for non\sphinxhyphen{}enzymatic proteins.

\sphinxstylestrong{Plotting}. The model can be observed only with the instantation of
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Observables}} (\sphinxhref{https://pysb.readthedocs.io/en/stable/tutorial.html\#simulation-and-analysis}{More here}).
Run \sphinxstyleemphasis{Monomer+Initials+Observables from metabolic network.ipynb} to obtain
automatically the all possible \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Observables}} for enzymatic proteins. Other
observables for proteins should be added manually.
\end{sphinxadmonition}


\section{Transcription Factor\sphinxhyphen{}DNA Binding Site Interaction Networks}
\label{\detokenize{NetTFsDNABindingSites:transcription-factor-dna-binding-site-interaction-networks}}\label{\detokenize{NetTFsDNABindingSites:net-tfsdnabindingsites}}\label{\detokenize{NetTFsDNABindingSites::doc}}
The transcription factor\sphinxhyphen{}DNA binding site network represents the physical
interaction bewteen proteins and DNA. The network have two columns and for the
former network, the first column lists using comma all components of a TF
enclosed in brackets (optionally with small compounds) and in the second column
declares the DNA binding site. Users should use the prefix “SMALL\sphinxhyphen{}” for small
compounds and the prefix “BS\sphinxhyphen{}” to encode DNA binding sites using unique names.
The second type of GRN shows in the first column the RNA polymerase holoenzyme
complex (components in brackets) and in the second the promoter. Users should
name promoters with the gene name followed by the suffix “\sphinxhyphen{}pro\#” where \# is an
integer.

Examples:

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\},numbers=left,firstnumber=1,stepnumber=1]
\PYG{n}{SOURCE}	\PYG{n}{TARGET}
\PYG{c+c1}{\PYGZsh{} araBAD and araC}
\PYG{p}{[}\PYG{n}{crp}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{SMALL}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{n}{CAMP}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{crp}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{SMALL}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{n}{CAMP}\PYG{p}{]}	\PYG{n}{BS}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{l+m+mi}{83}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{l+m+mi}{104}

Finally, execute the “\sphinxstyleemphasis{Rules from tf\sphinxhyphen{}tfbs.ipynb}” to obtain the
\sphinxstyleemphasis{Rules} to model the defined interaction network. The complete rule\sphinxhyphen{}based
model can be found in the arabinose folder from the Network Biology Lab
GitHub repository \sphinxhref{https://github.com/networkbiolab/atlas/blob/master/arabinose/Model\%20arabinose\%20operon\%20Met\%20\%2B\%20PPI\%20\%2B\%20TXTL\%20\%2B\%20GRN.ipynb}{here}.

\end{sphinxVerbatim}

\begin{sphinxadmonition}{note}{Note:}
\sphinxstylestrong{Reversibility of reactions}. Atlas writes dead \sphinxstyleemphasis{Rules} for each
reaction declared in the network file. The \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Parameter(\textquotesingle{}fwd\_ReactionName\textquotesingle{}, 0))}}
must be set to non\sphinxhyphen{}zero to activate the rule and \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Parameter(\textquotesingle{}rvs\_ReactionName\textquotesingle{}, 0))}}
must be set to non\sphinxhyphen{}zero to define a reversible reaction.
\end{sphinxadmonition}

\begin{sphinxadmonition}{note}{Note:}
\sphinxstylestrong{Simulation}. The model can be simulated only with the instantiation of
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Monomers}} and \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Initials}} (\sphinxhref{https://pysb.readthedocs.io/en/stable/tutorial.html\#introduction}{More here}).
Run \sphinxstyleemphasis{Monomer+Initials+Observables from metabolic network.ipynb} to obtain
automatically the necessary \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Monomers}} and \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Initials}} (including
proteins and enzymatic complexes).

\sphinxstylestrong{Plotting}. The model can be observed only with the instantation of
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Observables}} (\sphinxhref{https://pysb.readthedocs.io/en/stable/tutorial.html\#simulation-and-analysis}{More here}).
Run \sphinxstyleemphasis{Monomer+Initials+Observables from metabolic network.ipynb} to obtain
automatically the all possible \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Observables}} for metabolites.
\end{sphinxadmonition}


\section{Sigma Factor\sphinxhyphen{}Promoter Interaction Networks}
\label{\detokenize{NetSFsPromoters:sigma-factor-promoter-interaction-networks}}\label{\detokenize{NetSFsPromoters:net-sfspromoters}}\label{\detokenize{NetSFsPromoters::doc}}
The Sigma Factor\sphinxhyphen{}Promoter network have two columns and for the former network, the first column lists using comma all components of a TF enclosed in brackets (optionally with small compounds) and in the second column declares the DNA binding site. Users should use the prefix “SMALL\sphinxhyphen{}” for small compounds and the prefix “BS\sphinxhyphen{}” to encode DNA binding sites using unique names. The second type of GRN shows in the first column the RNA polymerase holoenzyme complex (components in brackets) and in the second the promoter. Users should name promoters with the gene name followed by the suffix “\sphinxhyphen{}pro\#” where \# is an integer.

Examples:

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\},numbers=left,firstnumber=1,stepnumber=1]
\PYG{n}{SOURCE}	\PYG{n}{TARGET}
\PYG{c+c1}{\PYGZsh{} Docking to promoters}
\PYG{p}{[}\PYG{n}{rpoA}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{rpoA}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{rpoB}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{rpoC}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{rpoD}\PYG{p}{]}	\PYG{n}{BS}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{n}{rpoA}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{n}{pro1}
\PYG{p}{[}\PYG{n}{rpoA}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{rpoA}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{rpoB}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{rpoC}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{rpoD}\PYG{p}{]}	\PYG{n}{BS}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{n}{rpoB}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{n}{pro1}
\PYG{c+c1}{\PYGZsh{} [rpoA, rpoA, rpoB, rpoC, rpoD]	BS\PYGZhy{}rpoC\PYGZhy{}pro1}
\PYG{p}{[}\PYG{n}{rpoA}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{rpoA}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{rpoB}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{rpoC}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{rpoD}\PYG{p}{]}	\PYG{n}{BS}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{n}{rpoD}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{n}{pro1}

\PYG{p}{[}\PYG{n}{rpoA}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{rpoA}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{rpoB}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{rpoC}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{rpoE}\PYG{p}{]}	\PYG{n}{BS}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{n}{rpoD}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{n}{pro1}

Finally, execute the “\sphinxstyleemphasis{Rules from SigmaFactors x Architecture.ipynb}” to obtain the
\sphinxstyleemphasis{Rules} to model the defined interaction network. The complete rule\sphinxhyphen{}based
model can be found in the sigma folder from the Network Biology Lab
GitHub repository \sphinxhref{https://github.com/networkbiolab/atlas/blob/master/sigma/Model\%20sigma.ipynb/}{here}.

\end{sphinxVerbatim}

\begin{sphinxadmonition}{note}{Note:}
\sphinxstylestrong{Reversibility of reactions}. Atlas writes dead \sphinxstyleemphasis{Rules} for each
reaction declared in the network file. The \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Parameter(\textquotesingle{}fwd\_ReactionName\textquotesingle{}, 0))}}
must be set to non\sphinxhyphen{}zero to activate the rule and \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Parameter(\textquotesingle{}rvs\_ReactionName\textquotesingle{}, 0))}}
must be set to non\sphinxhyphen{}zero to define a reversible reaction.
\end{sphinxadmonition}

\begin{sphinxadmonition}{note}{Note:}
\sphinxstylestrong{Simulation}. The model can be simulated only with the instantiation of
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Monomers}} and \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Initials}} (\sphinxhref{https://pysb.readthedocs.io/en/stable/tutorial.html\#introduction}{More here}).
Run \sphinxstyleemphasis{Monomer+Initials+Observables from metabolic network.ipynb} to obtain
automatically the necessary \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Monomers}} and \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Initials}} (including
proteins and enzymatic complexes).

\sphinxstylestrong{Plotting}. The model can be observed only with the instantation of
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Observables}} (\sphinxhref{https://pysb.readthedocs.io/en/stable/tutorial.html\#simulation-and-analysis}{More here}).
Run \sphinxstyleemphasis{Monomer+Initials+Observables from metabolic network.ipynb} to obtain
automatically the all possible \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Observables}} for metabolites.
\end{sphinxadmonition}


\section{Genome Graphs}
\label{\detokenize{NetGenomeGraphs:genome-graphs}}\label{\detokenize{NetGenomeGraphs:net-genomegraphs}}\label{\detokenize{NetGenomeGraphs::doc}}
Metabolic networks have four columns. The first declares a unique name for the
enzyme or enzymatic complex; the second declares a unique name for the reaction;
the third column lists using comma unique names for substrates; and the last row
list using comma unique names for products. To declare metabolites located at
the periplasm or extracellular compartments, the user should employ the prefix
“PER\sphinxhyphen{}” and “EX\sphinxhyphen{}”, respectively. Use \sphinxstyleemphasis{spontaneous} for non\sphinxhyphen{}enzymatic reactions.

Examples:

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\},numbers=left,firstnumber=1,stepnumber=1]
\PYG{n}{SOURCE}	\PYG{n}{TARGET}
\PYG{n}{araB}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{n}{pro1}	\PYG{n}{araB}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{n}{rbs}
\PYG{n}{araB}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{n}{rbs}	\PYG{n}{araB}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{n}{cds}
\PYG{n}{araB}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{n}{cds}	\PYG{n}{araA}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{n}{rbs}
\PYG{n}{araA}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{n}{rbs}	\PYG{n}{araA}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{n}{cds}
\PYG{n}{araA}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{n}{cds}	\PYG{n}{araD}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{n}{rbs}
\PYG{n}{araD}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{n}{rbs}	\PYG{n}{araD}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{n}{cds}
\PYG{n}{araD}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{n}{cds}	\PYG{n}{araD}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{n}{ter1}

\PYG{n}{araC}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{n}{pro1}	\PYG{n}{araC}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{n}{BS}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{l+m+mi}{56}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{l+m+mi}{72}
\PYG{n}{araC}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{n}{BS}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{l+m+mi}{56}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{l+m+mi}{72}	\PYG{n}{araC}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{n}{rbs}
\PYG{n}{araC}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{n}{rbs}	\PYG{n}{araC}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{n}{cds}

\noindent\sphinxincludegraphics{{Fig_GenomeGraphs}.png}
\end{sphinxadmonition}

Finally, execute the “\sphinxstyleemphasis{Rules from metabolic network.ipynb}” to obtain the
\sphinxstyleemphasis{Rules} to model the defined network. If using a Sigma Factor\sphinxhyphen{}Promoter
Interaction Network, the user could use “\sphinxstyleemphasis{Rules from SigmaFactors x Architecture}”
to obtain the \sphinxstyleemphasis{Rules} to model both network at once. The complete rule\sphinxhyphen{}based
model can be found in the arabinose folder (1st example) and in the sigma
folder (2nd example) from the Network Biology Lab GitHub repository \sphinxhref{https://github.com/networkbiolab/atlas/}{here}.

\begin{sphinxadmonition}{note}{Note:}
\sphinxstylestrong{Kappa BioBrick Framework.} The \sphinxstyleemphasis{Rules} for transcription and translation
come from the work of Stewart and Wilson\sphinxhyphen{}Kanamori (See more
\sphinxhref{https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S1571066111001289}{here}).
A “pure” genome graph uses the originally defined rules, while a genome
graph + sigma factor specifity uses a modified \sphinxstyleemphasis{rules} to model the release
of the sigma factor from the RNA Polymerase at the transcription
initiation. Please note the explicit modeling of the RNA Polymerase complex in the
second example.

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\},numbers=left,firstnumber=1,stepnumber=1]
\PYG{n}{Rule}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{docking\PYGZus{}araB\PYGZus{}pro1}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{,}
	\PYG{n}{cplx}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{name} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{RNAP}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{dna} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{k+kc}{None}\PYG{p}{)} \PYG{o}{+} \PYG{n}{dna}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{name} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{araB}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nb}{type} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{pro1}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{prot} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{k+kc}{None}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{free} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{True}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{)} \PYG{o}{|}
	\PYG{n}{cplx}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{name} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{RNAP}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{dna} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{l+m+mi}{1}\PYG{p}{)} \PYG{o}{\PYGZpc{}} \PYG{n}{dna}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{name} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{araB}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nb}{type} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{pro1}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{prot} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{l+m+mi}{1}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{free} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{False}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{,}
	\PYG{n}{Parameter}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{fwd\PYGZus{}docking\PYGZus{}araB\PYGZus{}pro1}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{l+m+mi}{1}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{Parameter}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{rvs\PYGZus{}docking\PYGZus{}araB\PYGZus{}pro1}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{l+m+mi}{1}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{)}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

\sphinxstyleemphasis{OR}

	\PYG{n}{prot}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{name} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{rpoC}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{dna} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{k+kc}{None}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{met} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{k+kc}{None}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{up} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{l+m+mi}{3}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{dw} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{l+m+mi}{4}\PYG{p}{)} \PYG{o}{\PYGZpc{}}

	\PYG{n}{Parameter}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{fwd\PYGZus{}docking\PYGZus{}1\PYGZus{}rpoA\PYGZus{}rbs}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{l+m+mi}{1}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{,}
	\PYG{n}{Parameter}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{rvs\PYGZus{}docking\PYGZus{}1\PYGZus{}rpoA\PYGZus{}pro1}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{l+m+mi}{0}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{)}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}
\end{sphinxadmonition}

\begin{sphinxadmonition}{note}{Note:}
\sphinxstylestrong{Reversibility of reactions}. Atlas writes irreversible \sphinxstyleemphasis{Rules} for each
interaction between the RNA Polymerase and a promoter. The \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Parameter(\textquotesingle{}rvs\_ReactionName\textquotesingle{}, 0))}}
must be set to non\sphinxhyphen{}zero to define a reversible reaction. The remaining \sphinxstyleemphasis{Rules}
are irreversible without a way to define reversible reactions.
\end{sphinxadmonition}

\begin{sphinxadmonition}{note}{Note:}
\sphinxstylestrong{Simulation}. The model can be simulated only with the instantiation of
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Monomers}} and \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Initials}} (\sphinxhref{https://pysb.readthedocs.io/en/stable/tutorial.html\#introduction}{More here}).
Run \sphinxstyleemphasis{Monomer+Initials+Observables from metabolic network.ipynb} to obtain
automatically the necessary \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Monomers}} and \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Initials}} (including
proteins and enzymatic complexes). For initial genes, please refer to the
following example:

\sphinxstylestrong{Plotting}. The model can be observed only with the instantation of
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Observables}} (\sphinxhref{https://pysb.readthedocs.io/en/stable/tutorial.html\#simulation-and-analysis}{More here}).
Run \sphinxstyleemphasis{Monomer+Initials+Observables from metabolic network.ipynb} to obtain
automatically the all possible \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Observables}} for metabolites.
\end{sphinxadmonition}


\chapter{Simulation}
\label{\detokenize{Simulation:simulation}}\label{\detokenize{Simulation:simulation-page}}\label{\detokenize{Simulation::doc}}
Simulation could be done within the PySB python package (See more at \sphinxhref{https://pysb.readthedocs.io/en/stable/tutorial.html\#simulation-and-analysis}{PySB
documentation})
. Here is the relevant code that able the simulation of any PySB model, albeit
PySB exports the model, calls the simulator, and imports the results under the
hood. See {\hyperref[\detokenize{Plotting:plotting-page}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{std,std-ref}{Plotting}}}} for a simple example on how to plot simulation results.

\fvset{hllines={, 7, 8,}}%
\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\},numbers=left,firstnumber=1,stepnumber=1]
\PYG{k+kn}{from} \PYG{n+nn}{numpy} \PYG{k+kn}{import} \PYG{n}{linspace}
\PYG{k+kn}{from} \PYG{n+nn}{pysb}\PYG{n+nn}{.}\PYG{n+nn}{bng} \PYG{k+kn}{import} \PYG{n}{generate\PYGZus{}network}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{generate\PYGZus{}equations}
\PYG{k+kn}{from} \PYG{n+nn}{pysb}\PYG{n+nn}{.}\PYG{n+nn}{simulator} \PYG{k+kn}{import} \PYG{n}{ScipyOdeSimulator}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{BngSimulator}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{KappaSimulator}

\PYG{c+c1}{\PYGZsh{} modify accordingly}
\PYG{k+kn}{from} \PYG{n+nn}{pysb}\PYG{n+nn}{.}\PYG{n+nn}{pathfinder} \PYG{k+kn}{import} \PYG{n}{set\PYGZus{}path}
\PYG{n}{set\PYGZus{}path}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{bng}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{/opt/git\PYGZhy{}repositories/bionetgen.RuleWorld/bng2/}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{)}
\PYG{n}{set\PYGZus{}path}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{kasim}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{/opt/git\PYGZhy{}repositories/KaSim4.Kappa\PYGZhy{}Dev/}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{)}

\PYG{c+c1}{\PYGZsh{}\PYGZsh{} for network\PYGZhy{}based simulations:}
\PYG{c+c1}{\PYGZsh{}\PYGZsh{} ScipyOdeSimulator and BngSimulator ode and ssa methods}
\PYG{c+c1}{\PYGZsh{} generate\PYGZus{}network(model)}
\PYG{c+c1}{\PYGZsh{} generate\PYGZus{}equations(model)}

\PYG{c+c1}{\PYGZsh{}\PYGZsh{} set the number of stochastic simulations}
\PYG{n}{runs} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{l+m+mi}{100}
\PYG{c+c1}{\PYGZsh{} data1 = ScipyOdeSimulator(model, linspace(0, 100, 200)).run().dataframe}
\PYG{c+c1}{\PYGZsh{} data1 = BngSimulator(model, linspace(0, 200, 201)).run(method = \PYGZsq{}ode\PYGZsq{}).dataframe}
\PYG{c+c1}{\PYGZsh{} data2 = BngSimulator(model, linspace(0, 200, 201)).run(method = \PYGZsq{}ssa\PYGZsq{}, n\PYGZus{}runs = runs).dataframe}
\PYG{c+c1}{\PYGZsh{} data2 = BngSimulator(model, linspace(0, 200, 201)).run(method = \PYGZsq{}nf\PYGZsq{}, n\PYGZus{}runs = runs).dataframe}
\PYG{n}{data2} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{KappaSimulator}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{model}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{linspace}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+m+mi}{0}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{l+m+mi}{100}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{l+m+mi}{101}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{run}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{n\PYGZus{}runs} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{runs}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{dataframe}

\PYG{c+c1}{\PYGZsh{}\PYGZsh{} process simulations}
\PYG{n}{data} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{p}{[}\PYG{p}{]}
\PYG{k}{for} \PYG{n}{i} \PYG{o+ow}{in} \PYG{n+nb}{range}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+m+mi}{0}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{runs}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{:}
	\PYG{n}{data}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{append}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{data2}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{xs}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{i}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{)}

\PYG{n}{avrg} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{l+m+mi}{0}
\PYG{k}{for} \PYG{n}{i} \PYG{o+ow}{in} \PYG{n+nb}{range}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+m+mi}{0}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{runs}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{:}
	\PYG{n}{avrg} \PYG{o}{+}\PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{data}\PYG{p}{[}\PYG{n}{i}\PYG{p}{]}
\PYG{n}{avrg} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{avrg} \PYG{o}{/} \PYG{n}{runs}

\PYG{n}{stdv} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{l+m+mi}{0}
\PYG{k}{for} \PYG{n}{i} \PYG{o+ow}{in} \PYG{n+nb}{range}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+m+mi}{0}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{runs}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{:}
	\PYG{n}{stdv} \PYG{o}{+}\PYG{o}{=} \PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{data}\PYG{p}{[}\PYG{n}{i}\PYG{p}{]} \PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}} \PYG{n}{avrg}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{o}{*}\PYG{o}{*}\PYG{l+m+mi}{2}
\PYG{n}{stdv} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{stdv} \PYG{o}{/} \PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{runs}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{l+m+mi}{1}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{o}{*}\PYG{o}{*}\PYG{l+m+mf}{0.5}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}
\sphinxresetverbatimhllines

\begin{sphinxadmonition}{note}{Note:}
Please follow the instructions at \sphinxhref{https://github.com/RuleWorld/bionetgen}{BioNetGen}
and at \sphinxhref{https://github.com/Kappa-Dev/KaSim}{KaSim} documentations to install
the stochactic simulators. For network\sphinxhyphen{}based simulations (Ordinary Differential
Equations and Gillespie\textasciigrave{}s algorithm), BioNetGen is required to perform the network
generation. Change the corresponding paths (lines 7\sphinxhyphen{}8) to match the parent folder for
the BNG2.pl or KaSim executable.
\end{sphinxadmonition}


\chapter{Plotting}
\label{\detokenize{Plotting:plotting}}\label{\detokenize{Plotting:plotting-page}}\label{\detokenize{Plotting::doc}}
PySB could inform the results of a simulation to dataframes (See
{\hyperref[\detokenize{Simulation:simulation-page}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{std,std-ref}{Simulation}}}}) and visualization of results could be done with
matplotlib or seaborn even (\sphinxhref{https://seaborn.pydata.org/}{See more here}). To
access the data, the dataframes columns reproduce the names of the \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Observables}}.
The following example could be adapted to show the dynamics of any \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Observable}}.

\begin{sphinxadmonition}{note}{Note:}
Importantly, PySB allows the inspection of the model to find which
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Monomers}} (and complexes of monomers) exists in the model, but as the
simulation is network\sphinxhyphen{}free, the possible formed complexes are up to the user
concern.
\end{sphinxadmonition}

\begin{sphinxadmonition}{note}{Note:}
Atlas produces automatically \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Observables}} for metabolites, and other
components and complexes could also be observed and plotted, but their
declaration in the model is entirely up to the user.
\end{sphinxadmonition}

And the results is

\noindent\sphinxincludegraphics{{Fig_Arabinose}.png}

\begin{sphinxadmonition}{note}{Note:}
See the \sphinxhref{https://github.com/glucksfall/atlas/blob/master/arabinose/Model\%20arabinose\%20operon\%20Met\%20\%2B\%20PPI\%20\%2B\%20TXTL\%20\%2B\%20GRN.ipynb}{Arabinose Model}
to inspect the rules and reproduce (at some extent because of stochasticity) the plot showed in this Manual.
\end{sphinxadmonition}


\chapter{Export to}
\label{\detokenize{Export_to:export-to}}\label{\detokenize{Export_to::doc}}
The PySB python package could export to different languages
(See more \sphinxhref{https://pysb.readthedocs.io/en/stable/modules/export/}{here}).
Use the following code to export to BioNetGen and \sphinxstyleemphasis{kappa} languages, putting
the code at the end of the model.

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\},numbers=left,firstnumber=1,stepnumber=1]
\PYG{k+kn}{from} \PYG{n+nn}{pysb}\PYG{n+nn}{.}\PYG{n+nn}{export} \PYG{k+kn}{import} \PYG{n}{export}
\PYG{k}{with} \PYG{n+nb}{open}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{model.kappa}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{w}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{)} \PYG{k}{as} \PYG{n}{outfile}\PYG{p}{:}
	\PYG{n}{outfile}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{write}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{export}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{model}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{kappa}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{)}
\PYG{k}{with} \PYG{n+nb}{open}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{model.bngl}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{w}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{)} \PYG{k}{as} \PYG{n}{outfile}\PYG{p}{:}
	\PYG{n}{outfile}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{write}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{export}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{model}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{bngl}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{)}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

\begin{sphinxadmonition}{note}{Note:}
In the case of matlab, mathematica, and stochkit, PySB requires to expand
the rules to determine all mass\sphinxhyphen{}balances to write ODE\sphinxhyphen{}based models, a proccess
call network generation and could take excessive time to finish.
\end{sphinxadmonition}
